intro: Phoradendron serotinum var. macrotomum, commonly known as the giant mistletoe, is a parasitic plant that grows on various host trees, primarily in the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its dense, evergreen foliage and white, fleshy berries. The plant produces sticky seeds that are dispersed by birds, facilitating its spread to new host trees. Its leaves are typically broad and have a leathery texture, while its flowers are small and inconspicuous. The species is notable for its ability to form dense, bushy growths on its hosts, often creating a striking visual contrast in the forest canopy.
